children.value: One of the key challenges of reinforcement learning is the
actions we know will give high reward, or should we
different actions to discover potentially better strategies? An algorithm that doesn’t explore effectively might easily
to certain areas of the state space, and fail to generalize once they enter a region they haven’t yet seen. The algorithms we saw in the chapter on fitted DP
, where the state never changes so all we care about are the actions, we saw algorithms like
that incentivize the learner to explore arms that it is uncertain about. In this chapter, we will see how to generalize these ideas to the MDP setting.
To quantify the performance of a learning algorithm, we will consider its per-episode regret over

children.html: TTT

children.html: ttt

children.value: problems where reward doesn’t come until after many steps, and algorithms which do not
explore new states may fail to learn anything meaningful (within a reasonable amount of time).

For example, policy gradient algorithms require the gradient to be nonzero in order to learn. If we never observe any reward, the gradient will always be zero, and the policy will never change or improve.
Here’s a simple example of an MDP with sparse reward:

children.html: ∣S∣|\mathcal{S}|∣S∣

children.value: states. The agent starts in the leftmost state. In every state, there are three possible actions, two of which move the agent left and one which moves the agent right. The reward function assigns

children.html: r=1r=1r=1

children.value: . In this simple setting, there will be no “automatic” exploration due to randomness, so our strategy must actively explore new states. One simple strategy is to visit every possible state-action pair to learn the entire MDP. Then, once the MDP is known, we can use DP to solve for the optimal policy. (This should remind you of the

children.html: KKK
(s,a,r,s′)(s, a, r, s')(s,a,r,s′)

children.value: pairs we’ve observed. Each episode, we’ll choose an unseen state-action pair for which the reward and the next state are unknown, and take the shortest path there. We assume that every state can be reached from the initial state within a single episode.
The shortest path computation can be implemented using DP. We leave this as an exercise.

Treating an unknown MDP as a MAB
We also explored the exploration-exploitation tradeoff in
. Recall tthat in the MAB setting, we have

children.html: KKK

children.value: arms, each of which has an unknown reward distribution, and we want to learn which of the arms is
, i.e. has the highest mean reward.
One algorithm that struck a good balance between exploration and exploitation was the
: For each arm, we construct a
for its true mean award, and then choose the arm with the highest upper confidence bound. In summary,

is optimal. So if we want to apply MAB techniques to solving an MDP, it makes sense to think of

children.value: , which quickly becomes intractable. Notably, this method doesn’t consider the information that we gain across different policies. We can illustrate this with the following example:
Treating an MDP as a MAB
Consider a “coin MDP” with two states “heads” and “tails”, two actions “Y” and “N”, and a time horizon of

children.html: H=2\hor=2H=2

children.value: . The state transition flips the coin, and doesn’t depend on the action. The reward only depends on the action: Taking action Y gives reward
, and taking action N gives reward
Suppose we collect data from the two constant policies

children.value: Putting these parts together, we can define the algorithm as follows:

children.label: ucb-vi-alg
children.html: 3+1=43 + 1 = 43+1=4

children.value: How exactly does UCB-VI strike a good balance between exploration and exploitation? In UCB for MABs, the bonus exploration term is simple to interpret: It encourages the learner to take actions with a high exploration term. Here, the policy depends on the bonus term indirectly: The policy is obtained by planning in an MDP where the bonus term is added to the reward function. Note that the bonuses
in DP, effectively enabling the learner to
unknown states. This effect takes some further interpretation.

children.html: bhtb^t_\hibht​
Vh⋆(s)≤V^ht(s)V^\star_\hi(s) \le \hat{V}_\hi^t(s)Vh⋆​(s)≤V^ht​(s)
Vh⋆(s)−Vhπt(s)≤V^ht(s)−Vhπt(s).V^\star_\hi(s) - V^{\pi^t}_\hi(s) \le \hat{V}_\hi^t(s) - V^{\pi^t}_\hi(s).Vh⋆​(s)−Vhπt​(s)≤V^ht​(s)−Vhπt​(s).

    Q^\star_\hi(s, a)  & = r_\hi(s, a) + \E_{s' \sim P_\hi(\cdot \mid s, a)} [V^\star_{h+1}(s')]                          \\

children.value: Now, to design the reward bonus, we can’t apply Hoeffding anymore, since the terms no longer involve sample means of bounded random variables; Instead, we’re incorporating information across different states and actions. Rather, we can construct an upper bound using
in the same way we did for the LinUCB algorithm in the MAB setting

children.html: bht(s,a)=βϕ(s,a)⊤(Aht)−1ϕ(s,a),β=O~(dH).b^t_\hi(s, a) = \beta \sqrt{\phi(s, a)^\top (A^t_h)^{-1} \phi(s, a)}, \quad \beta = \tilde O(d \hor).bht​(s,a)=βϕ(s,a)⊤(Aht​)−1ϕ(s,a)​,β=O~(dH).

children.value: Note that this isn’t explicitly inversely proportional to

children.html: Nht(s,a)N_h^t(s, a)Nht​(s,a)

children.value: as in the original UCB-VI bonus term
. Rather, it is inversely proportional to the amount that the direction

children.html: ϕ(s,a)\phi(s, a)ϕ(s,a)

children.value: has been explored in the history. That is, if

children.html: AhtA_h^tAht​

children.value: has a large component in the direction

children.html: ϕ(s,a)\phi(s, a)ϕ(s,a)

children.value: , implying that this direction is well explored, then the bonus term will be small, and vice versa.
We can now plug in these transition estimates and reward bonuses into the UCB-VI algorithm
The LinUCB-VI algorithm achieves expected regret

children.html: E[RegretT]=E[∑t=0T−1V0⋆(s0)−V0πt(s0)]≤O~(H2d1.5T)\E[\text{Regret}_T] = \E\left[\sum_{t=0}^{T-1} V^\star_0(s_0) - V^{\pi^t}_0(s_0) \right] \le \tilde O(H^2 d^{1.5} \sqrt{T})E[RegretT​]=E[t=0∑T−1​V0⋆​(s0​)−V0πt​(s0​)]≤O~(H2d1.5T​)

children.value: Comparing this to our bound for UCB-VI in an environment without this linear assumption, we see that we go from a sample complexity of

children.html: Ω~(H4∣S∣∣A∣)\tilde \Omega(H^4 |\mathcal{S}||\mathcal{A}|)Ω~(H4∣S∣∣A∣)
Ω~(H4d3)\tilde \Omega(H^4 d^{3})Ω~(H4d3)

children.value: . This new sample complexity only depends on the feature dimension and not on the state or action space of the MDP!
In this chapter, we’ve explored how to explore in an unknown MDP.
We first discussed the explore-then-exploit algorithm
, a simple way to explore a deterministic MDP by visiting all state-action pairs.
We then discussed how to treat an unknown MDP as a MAB
Treating an unknown MDP as a MAB
, and how this approach is inefficient since it doesn’t make use of relationships between policies.
We then introduced the UCB-VI algorithm
, which models the unknown MDP by a proxy MDP with a reward bonus term that encourages exploration.
Finally, assuming that the transitions and rewards are linear with respect to a feature transformation of the state and action, we introduced the LinUCB-VI algorithm
, which has a sample complexity independent of the size of the state and action spaces.
